sentences.sentence: The Fortune( 命运 )-Teller
A fortune( 命运 )-teller sat in the market-place and told the fortunes( 命运 ) of all who paid him.
Suddenly a man ran to him and told him, “Thieves( 小偷 ) have broken into your house and taken everything.”
He was up in a moment, and rushed off( 匆忙离开 ), tearing( 撕扯 ) his hair and calling down curses( 诅咒 ) on the thieves( 小偷 ).
The bystanders( 旁观者 ) were much amused( 被逗乐的 ), and one of them said,
“Our friend claims to know what is going to happen to others,
but it seems he’s not clever enough to see what’s in his own future.”
MORAL: Those who help others often cannot help themselves.
The Fox( 狐狸 ) and the Crow( 乌鸦 )
A crow( 乌鸦 ), after stealing some meat, held it in her mouth, and sat in a tree.
A fox( 狐狸 ), seeing her, wanted the meat.
“How handsome the crow( 乌鸦 ) is,” he said, “in the beauty of her body and her feathers( 羽毛 )!
Oh, if her voice were as beautiful as her, she could be the Queen of birds!”
The crow( 乌鸦 ) was pleased by the fox( 狐狸 )’s nice words.
Anxious( 急切的 ) to prove( 证明 ) her voice was also beautiful, she started to sing, and dropped the meat.
The fox( 狐狸 ) quickly picked it up( 捡起 ), and said to the crow( 乌鸦 ),
“Thank you! The beauty of your voice is equalled only by your intelligence( 智力 ).”
MORAL: Don’t listen to flattery( 恭维话 ).
The Fox( 狐狸 ) and the Grapes
A hungry fox( 狐狸 ) saw some ripe( 成熟的 ) black grapes hanging very high up.
She tried all her tricks( 计谋 ) to get at them, but without success, for she could not reach them.
At last she turned away( 走开 ), hiding her disappointment( 失望 ) and saying,
“I can see that the grapes are sour( 酸的 ), and not ripe( 成熟的 ) as I thought.”
MORAL: We all like to criticize( 挑剔 ) what we cannot have.
The Fox( 狐狸 ) and the Lion
A fox( 狐狸 ) who had never seen a lion one day met one,
and was so terrified( 极度惊恐的 ) at the sight of him that he was ready to die with fear.
After a time he met him again, and was still rather frightened( 害怕的 ), but not as much as the first time they met.
But when he saw him for the third time,
he was so far from being afraid that he went up to him and began to talk to him as if he had known him all his life.
MORAL: What we see every day, we no longer fear.
The Fox( 狐狸 ) and the Stork( 鹳 )
A fox( 狐狸 ) invited a stork( 鹳 ) to dinner, and only offered his guest some soup in a wide, shallow( 浅的 ) dish.
He could eat this easily, but the stork( 鹳 ), who could only put the end of his beak( 鸟喙 ) into the soup, had trouble.
A few days after, the stork( 鹳 ) invited the fox( 狐狸 ) to dinner.
He brought some meat in a jar( 罐子 ) to the table.
The neck of the jar( 罐子 ) was deep and narrow( 窄的 ), so that, the stork( 鹳 ) could eat very well, but the fox( 狐狸 ) couldn’t.
The fox( 狐狸 ) was angry, but realized that he had been treated as he deserved( 应得 ).
MORAL: Those who trick( 戏弄 ) others will be tricked( 戏弄 ) in their turn.
The Fox( 狐狸 ), the Rooster( 公鸡 ), and the Dog
One night a fox( 狐狸 ) was looking for something to eat, and saw a rooster( 公鸡 ) sitting on a post, too high for him to reach.
So he said to the rooster( 公鸡 ), “Good news! King Lion has ordered that for the next week,
no animal may hurt or kill any other animal, and we can all live together in peace!”
The rooster( 公鸡 ) replied, “That is good news! In that case, why don’t we go over and have a friendly talk with the farmer’s dog over there?”
“I would love to do that,” said the fox( 狐狸 ),
“But I am afraid he may not have heard the good news from King Lion yet.”
MORAL: If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is.

article_info.previous: 在昨天的故事里，一只鹳和一群鹤被农夫抓住，即使鹳没有损害农夫的粮食，他仍然会像鹤一样受到惩罚，因为他是和鹤一起被抓的。这个故事告诉我们人们会根据其同伴和所处团伙来评价一个人。
article_info.share_words: We all like to criticize what we cannot have.   What we see every day, we no longer fear.

question.cn: 在故事The Fox and the Crow中，为什么狐狸会赞扬乌鸦？
question.en: In the story The Fox and the Crow, why did the fox praise the crow?

options.en: The fox wanted to eat the crow.
The fox fell in love with the crow.

options.cn: 狐狸想要乌鸦嘴中的肉。
options.en: The fox wanted the meat in the crow's mouth.

analysis: 文中提到：“A fox, seeing her, wanted the meat. . . ”然后狐狸设计陷阱让乌鸦张口导致“She started to sing and dropped the meat. The fox quickly picked it up.” 因此选C。

question.cn: 在故事The Fox and the Grapes，狐狸吃到葡萄了吗？
question.en: In the story the Fox and the Grapes, did the fox eat the grapes?

analysis: 文中提到：“She tried all her tricks to get at them, but without success, for she could not reach them.”可知，狐狸并没有吃到葡萄，所以选B。

question.cn: 在故事The Fox and the Stork中，狐狸用什么给鹳呈上食物？
question.en: In the story The Fox and the Stork, what did the fox use to serve food to the stork?

analysis: 文中提到：“A fox invited a stork to dinner, and only offer his guest some soup in a wide, shallow dish.”因此选B。

question.cn: 在故事The Fox, the Rooster, and the Dog中，狐狸最后有没有吃到公鸡？
question.en: In the story The Fox, the Rooster, and the Dog, did the fox finally get to eat the rooster?

analysis: 文中提到公鸡对狐狸说：“Why don't we go over and have a friendly talk with the farmer's dog over there？”可见，公鸡并没有因为狐狸的话而对其放松警惕，可以推断最后狐狸没有吃到公鸡，因此选B。

share_title: 100天读完3本英文书，今天是第11天
